sect1.title: Configuring the Boot Loader with &yast;
sect1.para: The easiest way to configure the boot loader in your &productname; system is to use the &yast; module. In the &yast; Control Center, select System Boot Loader. As in , this shows the current boot loader configuration of your system and allows you to make changes.

Use the Section Management tab to edit, change and delete boot loader sections for the individual operating systems. To add an option, click Add. To change the value of an existing option, select it with the mouse and click Edit. To remove an existing entry, select it and click Delete. If you are not familiar with boot loader options, read first.
Use the Boot Loader Installation tab to view and change settings related to type, location and advanced loader settings.

Click Other to access advanced configuration options. The build-in editor lets you change the &grub; configuration files. For details, see . You can also delete the existing configuration and Start from Scratch or let &yast; Propose a New Configuration. It is also possible to write the configuration to disk or reread the configuration from the disk. To restore the original Master Boot Record (MBR) that was saved during the installation, choose Restore MBR of Hard Disk.

sect2.title: Adjusting the Default Boot Entry
sect2.para: To change the system that is booted by default, proceed as follows:

step.para: Open the Section Management tab.
Select the desired entry from the list.
Click Set as Default.
Click OK to activate these changes.

sect2.title: Modifying the Boot Loader Location
sect2.para: To modify the location of the boot loader, follow these steps:

step.para: Select the Boot Loader Installation tab and then choose one of the following options for Boot Loader Location:

listitem.para: This installs the boot loader in the MBR of the first disk (according to the boot sequence preset in the BIOS).
This installs the boot loader in the boot sector of the / partition (this is the default).
This installs the boot loader in the boot sector of the /boot partition.
This installs the boot loader in the extended partition container.
Use this option to specify the location of the boot loader manually.

step.para: Click OK to apply your changes.

sect2.title: Changing the Boot Loader Time-Out
sect2.para: The boot loader does not boot the default system immediately. During the time-out, you can select the system to boot or write some kernel parameters. To set the boot loader time-out, proceed as follows:

step.para: Open the Boot Loader Installation tab.
Click Boot Loader Options.
Change the value of Time-Out in Seconds by typing in a new value and clicking the appropriate arrow key with your mouse, or by using the arrow keys on the keyboard.
Click OK twice to save the changes.

warning.title: Timeout of 0 Seconds
warning.para: When setting the timeout to 0 seconds, you will not be able to access &grub; during boot time. When having set the default boot option to a non-Linux operation system at the same time, this effectively disables access to the Linux system.

sect2.title: Setting a Boot Password
sect2.para: Using this &yast; module, you can also set a password to protect booting. This gives you an additional level of security.

step.para: Open the Boot Loader Installation tab.
Click Boot Loader Options.
Activate the Protect Boot Loader with Password option with a click and type in your Password twice.
Click OK twice to save the changes.

sect2.title: Adjusting the Disk Order

step.para: Open the Boot Loader Installation tab.
Click Boot Loader Installation Details.
If more than one disk is listed, select a disk and click Up or Down to reorder the displayed disks.
Click OK two times to save the changes.

sect2.title: Configuring Advanced Options
sect2.para: Advanced boot options can be configured via Boot Loader Installation Boot Loader Options. Normally, it should not be necessary to change the default settings.

term.guimenu: Set Active Flag in Partition Table for Boot Partition

listitem.para: Activates the partition that contains the boot loader. Some legacy operating systems (such as Windows 98) can only boot from an active partition.

term.guimenu: Write Generic Boot Code to MBR

listitem.para: Replaces the current MBR with generic, operating system independent code.
Sets &grub; in debug mode where it displays messages to show disk activity.
Hides the boot menu and boots the default entry.

warning.para: When hiding the boot menu, you will not be able to access &grub; during boot time. When having set the default boot option to a non-Linux operation system at the same time, this effectively disables access to the Linux system.

listitem.para: Starts the Trusted &grub; which supports trusted computing functionality.
Enables or disables acoustic signals in &grub;.
Path to the graphics file used when displaying the boot screen.
If your machine is controlled via a serial console, activate this option and specify which COM port to use at which speed. See info grub or

sect2.title: Changing Boot Loader Type
sect2.para: Set the boot loader type in Boot Loader Installation. The default boot loader in &productname; is &grub;. To use &lilo; or ELILO, proceed as follows:

warning.title: &lilo; is unsupported
warning.para: Using &lilo; is not recommended—it is unsupported on &productname;. Only use it in special cases.

step.para: Select the Boot Loader Installation tab.
For Boot Loader, select LILO.
In the dialog box that opens, select one of the following actions:

listitem.para: Have &yast; convert the current configuration. When converting the configuration, some settings may be lost.
Write a custom configuration. This action is not available during the installation of &productname;.
Load your own /etc/lilo.conf. This action is not available during the installation of &productname;.

step.para: Click OK two times to save the changes.

sect2.para: During the conversion, the old &grub; configuration is saved to the disk. To use it, simply change the boot loader type back to &grub; and choose Restore Configuration Saved before Conversion. This action is available only on an installed system.

note.title: Custom Boot Loader
note.para: To use a boot loader other than &grub; or &lilo;, select Do Not Install Any Boot Loader. Read the documentation of your boot loader carefully before choosing this option.
